awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: Some Error Correcting Codes for Computer Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Error control codes play a major role in achieving high reliable operations of modern computer systems, DVDs, cameras, etc. In this project new classes of error correcting codes suitable for high density flash memories are to be developed. The market revenue of flash memories is estimated to be $100B per year. The PI has close collaboration with leading Flash memory industry (Micron). While this enables development of error correcting codes specifically in the practical context of applications, the results of this research will not only be easily transitioned to industry, it will also train students, postdocs and future industry researchers via lectures, seminars and course development at the PIs institution. 

In this project, multi-level flash, in which each cell can have 4 or 8 voltage levels, will be considered. Experiments indicate that the bit error rate of flash memory worsens as the Program/Erasure count increases. In addition, it is observed that most of the errors are of limited magnitude and of decreasing type. Study of error statistics of error characteristics justify that the L1 distance codes are more suitable to overcome errors in flash memories. New classes of L1 distance codes are to be developed using the concepts of elementary symmetric functions. The project will also consider the design of error correcting codes for insertion and deletion of repeated symbols in high speed data bus and communication systems. Furthermore, the theory and codes to be developed for flash memories can potentially be extended to design efficient high-ordered-spectral-null codes for optical discs and magnetic memories.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project are to design efficient limited magnitude error correcting codes applicable to flash memories and error correcting code designs for insertion and deletion of repeated symbols. It is also planned to design high ordered spectral null codes applicable to storage systems.

 The outcomes:

1, We have developed optimal limited magnitude all error correcting codes. In 1956, Shannon introduced the concept of 'zero error capacity', which means that codes which use minimum number of redundant check digits and at the same time make the probability of digit error zero while transmitting the codewords through the error channel.  Till now no code is known to achieve this rate. We have proved that the new class of limited magnitude all error correcting codes designed by us achieve the Shannon's zero error capacities. Some preliminary results have been presented at the Information Theory and Applications Workshop at UC San Diego in February 2016 and also in 2017. A paper describing some new results on this area has been published at the International Symposium on Information Theory, June/July 2017. In addition, a paper describing these results has been published in the January 2018 issue of IEEE Transactions on Information Theory.

2. We have also designed efficient codes correcting t-errors in L_1 metric (limited magnitude errors) using the new concept of elementary function theory and showed how these codes can be successfully applied to flash memories to correct the predominant errors. A paper describing these results has been presented at the Information Theory and Applications Workshop at San Diego in 2015 and also in the International Symposium on Information Theory, June 2018.

3. Efficient second-ordered-spectral-null codes applicable to magnetic storage systems are developed and a paper describing these results has been published in IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, June 2016.

4. Gray codes in vectors over Gaussian integers are developed. How these Gray codes are useful in finding edge disjoint Hamiltonian cycles in Gaussian and Torus networks has been developed. These results have been published in the October 2016 issue of IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed System.

5. Designed error correcting codes for insertion and deletion of 0's in a data word. We showed that this problem is related to limited magnitude error correcting codes and so, the codes correcting t-errors in L_1 metric using the elementary symmetric function can be directly used to solve this problem. A paper related to this topic has been presented at the Information Theory and Application Workshop, San Diego, in February 2018. In addition, a paper describing these results has been published in the proceedings of the International Symposium on Information Theory, 2019.

With this NSF grant support, we have published 7 journal papers and  3 conference papers. Also made 4 conference and workshop presentations.

Three Ph.D. graduates have been partially supported by this grant.
